p: Most importantly, the CD8 + T-cell immunosurveillance of viruses is dependent on human leucocyte antigen class I (HLA-I) molecules that are expressed on the surface of all nucleated cells. Genetic differences in HLA alleles have been recently recognised to confer differential viral susceptibility and severity of COVID-19 [ 19]. Data validated in two independent cohorts of patients with cancer receiving ICIs revealed that heterozygous HLA-I genotypes were associated with better survival than homozygosity for one or more HLA-I genes, and treatment efficacy was diminished by loss of HLA-I heterozygosity [ 20]. These findings highlight that genetic variability in the immune system may affect susceptibility to (and severity of) SARS-CoV-2; therefore, strategies to boost immune responses at this stage are certainly important for individuals particularly vulnerable to COVID-19.
